posts.author: TheRedPilledArtist
posts.title: 👿 You can't make a deal with a Demon who only wants bloodshed; he must be defeated.

posts.raw_content:
Today, I am inspired by the book of John 13:34, “A new command I give you: Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another.”

As we start this new season of light, and growth I want to talk about “Spiritual renewal” —a refreshing of our hearts to align with God’s. Sometimes, we come to God with requests: a new job, healing, or a relationship. We knock, we seek, we ask, as Jesus taught in Matthew 7:7. But what happens when God says “no”? What do we do when our prayers seem to hit a wall?

Picture a young man, kneeling in prayer, asking God for success, for provision, for love. Each time, he hears a gentle but firm “no” from the Lord. Frustrated, he cries out, “Why, God? Why won’t you give me what I’m asking for?” And in the stillness, the Spirit whispers, “Ask for something greater.” Confused, he prays, “Lord, teach me to love someone as much as you love me.” And for the first time, God says, “Yes.”

This shift changes everything. You see, when we ask for things—good things, even—we often focus on our desires. But when we ask to love as God loves, we’re asking for His heart. Jesus’ love is selfless, sacrificial, unending. It’s the love that led Him to the cross (John 15:13). It’s the love that transforms us from the inside out. When God says “no” to our requests, it’s not because He’s withholding; it’s because He’s preparing us for something better—His love working through us.

Spiritual renewal begins when we stop asking for what we want and start asking for what God wants. Imagine praying, “Lord, let me love my neighbor, my enemy, my family, as you love me.” That prayer aligns us with God’s will. It renews our strength, as Isaiah 40:31 promises, because it roots us in His purpose. It’s not easy—loving like Jesus means forgiving, serving, sacrificing. But it’s the path to soaring like eagles, to running without weariness.

So today, let’s ask boldly for God’s heart. When He says “no” to our plans, trust He’s saying “yes” to something greater. Pray to love as He loves, and watch how He renews your spirit.
posts.author: Trumpican
posts.title: Today I was asked to give a guest sermon about “Spiritual Renewal.” Here is the text of my sermon. May you all have a blessed June.
posts.content:
Today, I am inspired by the book of John 13:34, “A new command I give you: Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another.”

As we start this new season of light, and growth I want to talk about “Spiritual renewal” —a refreshing of our hearts to align with God’s. Sometimes, we come to God with requests: a new job, healing, or a relationship. We knock, we seek, we ask, as Jesus taught in Matthew 7:7. But what happens when God says “no”? What do we do when our prayers seem to hit a wall?

Picture a young man, kneeling in prayer, asking God for success, for provision, for love. Each time, he hears a gentle but firm “no” from the Lord. Frustrated, he cries out, “Why, God? Why won’t you give me what I’m asking for?” And in the stillness, the Spirit whispers, “Ask for something greater.” Confused, he prays, “Lord, teach me to love someone as much as you love me.” And for the first time, God says, “Yes.”

This shift changes everything. You see, when we ask for things—good things, even—we often focus on our desires. But when we ask to love as God loves, we’re asking for His heart. Jesus’ love is selfless, sacrificial, unending. It’s the love that led Him to the cross (John 15:13). It’s the love that transforms us from the inside out. When God says “no” to our requests, it’s not because He’s withholding; it’s because He’s preparing us for something better—His love working through us.

Spiritual renewal begins when we stop asking for what we want and start asking for what God wants. Imagine praying, “Lord, let me love my neighbor, my enemy, my family, as you love me.” That prayer aligns us with God’s will. It renews our strength, as Isaiah 40:31 promises, because it roots us in His purpose. It’s not easy—loving like Jesus means forgiving, serving, sacrificing. But it’s the path to soaring like eagles, to running without weariness.

So today, let’s ask boldly for God’s heart. When He says “no” to our plans, trust He’s saying “yes” to something greater. Pray to love as He loves, and watch how He renews your spirit.
